user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DirectoryRead:
```c
int32 OS_DirectoryRead(osal_id_t dir_id, os_dirent_t *dirent)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(dirent);

    /* Make sure the file descriptor is legit before using it */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, dir_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        /*
         * Call the underlying implementation to perform the read
         *
         * NOTE: This does not map "virtual mount points" that
         * may appear in the dir listing back to the virtualized
         * name.  For instance, if the (real) /eeprom directory
         * is virtualized to /cf via the OS_VolumeTable, and one
         * reads the "/" directory, the application will see the
         * real name (eeprom) and not the virtualized name (cf).
         */
        return_code = OS_DirRead_Impl(&token, dirent);

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function for use of compiler-specific language extensions. The code contains only standard C constructs: a function definition, local variable declarations, pointer parameters, macro invocation (OS_CHECK_POINTER), function calls, comments, and return statements. There are no occurrences of common compiler extensions such as __attribute__, __asm__, typeof, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, labels-as-values (&&label), or other vendor-specific keywords or token sequences. The typedef-like identifiers (int32, osal_id_t, os_dirent_t, OS_object_token_t) are ordinary type names and not language extensions by themselves. The macro OS_CHECK_POINTER is invoked but its expansion is not shown in this fragment; the invocation alone is not evidence of a compiler extension. Therefore there are no code fragments in this snippet that should be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions).
